channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Obama Administration Tries to Prevent New Sanctions on Iran During Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry told a House committee that if nuclear negotiations fail, sanctions would then be needed.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry discussed Iran before a House committee on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Law Reduces Migrant Detention
item.description: The Israeli Parliament passed legislation on Tuesday allowing for the detention of African migrants and asylum seekers who enter the country illegally for up to a year without trial.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: French Troops Battle Islamists
item.description: French forces have killed 19 Islamist fighters during security operations in Mali’s northern region of Timbuktu, a senior French officer said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Qatar Signs Defense Accord With U.S.
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel met with the Qatari emir, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad, and Defense Minister Hamad bin Ali al-Attiyah on the last day of a visit to the region to reassure gulf Arab allies of continuing United States support.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: U.N. Forces Begin Campaign Against Rwandan Hutu Militia
item.description: United Nations peacekeeping troops have launched operations against a Rwandan Hutu rebel militia operating along the Democratic Republic of Congo’s border with Rwanda, the United Nations commander said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Great and the Humble Pay Tribute to Mandela
item.description: Nelson Mandela’s rain-swept memorial service drew tens of thousands of South Africans and a large crowd of global V.I.P.’s, including President Obama and more than 90 other heads of state and government.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN, NICHOLAS KULISH and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Well-wishers listened to the tributes to former South African President Nelson Mandela at the soccer stadium in Soweto.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: 13 Sunnis Killed, Then 12 Shiites
item.description: Seven Sunni construction workers were killed by unidentified gunmen who fired on them from a speeding S.U.V. in Abara, a majority-Sunni village in Diyala Province, police and medical officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Riot Police Push Into Kiev Square as Crisis Grows
item.description: Security forces early Wednesday stormed the central plaza in Kiev where protesters have been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Impasse Over Security Deal Adds to Afghan Economy’s Troubles
item.description: The business climate as worsened since President Hamid Karzai delayed his signing of the security deal, with rising food and fuel prices and a slump in lending and investment.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan women begged as a boy bought bread at a bakery in Kabul on Tuesday. Food and fuel prices have started to rise.

item.title: Uruguay Acts to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: Supporters said the move would remove the marijuana trade from the domain of illegal traffickers, allowing the authorities to regulate its consumption.
item.category: Institute for the Regulation and Control of Cannabis
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Thai Premier Rejects Demands That She Quit
item.description: Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra rejected demands by antigovernment protesters that she step aside before the country’s February elections.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra of Thailand on Tuesday after rejecting calls to step down.

item.title: The Lede: Leaders of Israel and Iran Praise Mandela, From a Safe Distance
item.description: As the crowd turned on South Africa’s president at the memorial for Nelson Mandela, and controversy surrounded a handshake, top officials in Israel and Iran may have been glad they had skipped the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Seven Sentenced to Prison Over Deadly Bridge Collapse
item.description: The failure of the bridge in Sichuan Province in July contributed to widespread concerns that construction projects in China are plagued by corruption.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The bridge in Sichuan Province had been refurbished shortly before it fell apart in flooding.

item.title: The Lede: Highlights From Memorial Service for Mandela
item.description: The service for Nelson Mandela included notable moments, selfies, tweets, images and videos being shared around the world.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Republican Says Iran Deal Should Halt Uranium Enrichment
item.description: Ed Royce, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, laid down a marker on a comprehensive Iran accord during a hearing that included testimony by Secretary of State John Kerry.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Rights Lawyer Among 4 Abducted in Syria; 2 Journalists Are Also Being Held
item.description: The abduction of the lawyer, Razan Zeitouneh, came hours after relatives and colleagues of two Spanish journalists kidnapped by Islamists in September in northern Syria made their plight public.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: The Lede: Show Us Your Scenes From Mandela’s Farewell
item.description: If you are in South Africa to pay tribute to Nelson Mandela, we invite you to share a photograph with us of the scenes and details you are witnessing at memorials and in the streets.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Prayers for Nelson Mandela at Heavenly Gate, a small church in Diepsloot, outside Johannesburg on Sunday.

item.title: After Mandela, a Test at the Polls for His Party
item.description: After the death of its most beloved leader, the African National Congress could face its most competitive elections since it came to power in 1994.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Diepsloot, a settlement north of Johannesburg, where other parties have made inroads on the African National Congress.

item.title: Chinese Professor Who Advocated Free Speech Is Fired
item.description: Zhang Xuezhong, who teaches at the East China University of Political Science and Law in Shanghai, has repeatedly called on the Chinese government to abide by its own Constitution.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Obama Reaches Out to Cuba’s Leader, but the Meaning May Elude Grasp
item.description: President Obama’s gesture to Raúl Castro of Cuba at the memorial for Nelson Mandela instantly raised questions about its deeper meaning.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Defective Breast Implant Sales Draw Prison Term for French Executive
item.description: The founder of Poly Implant Prothèse got four years in prison for selling hundreds of thousands of defective implants in more than 65 countries.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Letter from Europe: Vindication, of Sorts, for Austerity in Britain
item.description: Britain’s recent burst of economic growth calls for a re-examination of its unpopular austerity measures, which critics contend have hurt the country’s recovery.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: South Africa Faces Its Future
item.description: In the shadow of Nelson Mandela’s death, four South Africans ponder a future without the man who inspired and set so many free.

item.title: Obama, George W. Bush and Hillary Clinton Share Flight to South Africa
item.description: A former president, a current president and a potential candidate for president shared Air Force One for the flight to South Africa.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama, Michelle Obama, former President George W. Bush and Laura Bush arrived in Johannesburg.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 10
item.description: A demonstration on Human Rights Day in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An activist during a demonstration on Human Rights Day in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir. The day marks the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by the United Nations General Assembly.
